title: If objective moral values don’t exist, then how could you say Hitler’s actions were bad? - Quora

response.answer_text: Hitler’s actions were bad because he caused untold suffering and death using a dehumanising murdering machine that killed around 17 million people, robbed millions more of their freedom, and provoked a war that killed 85 million people and spread pseudo-science about racial superiority that survives to this day. The values that Hitler violated are not those of ‘objective reality’ - they are my values as a compassionate human being and those of my society. That is what makes it bad. I don’t have to refer to an external objective definition of badness in order to know that what Hitler did was an abhorrent violation of almost everything I hold dear. I have courage in my own convictions. I don’t need permission to be outraged and horrified. And what makes it more than just a personal opinion is that it is also a violation of shared moral principles of my society and which I subscribe to. In effect, the great majority of my society has consented to principles that define right and wrong and which we expect ourselves and others to abide by. And Hitler’s actions and those of his regime are such a gross violation of such principles that it can barely be overstated. It does not bother me that my moral outrage is not an objective fact. It does not bother me that from the perspective of Nazi ideology, those actions were good, or at least, a ‘necessary evil’. That does not mean that I have a moral duty to tolerate it. The actions taken by the Nazis and the world they wanted to build, would horrify anyone who cares about the welfare of human beings.

Recall that all words and all language acquire meaning depending on who is talking, Elementary example: the word “I“ Trivially takes it meaning based on who’s talking since in this post I, Timothy, am talking, Hitler’s actions were bad. The notion of speaker dependent language relieves me of the necessity of appending “in my opinion.” If Hitler Or a Hitler supporter (oops almost said a Trump supporter ha ha) were talking they would say “Hitler’s behavior was good.” both statements would be true by the law of speaker dependent language,

Hitler’s actions (the ones I assume you are referring to) were bad. There’s my subjective evaluation. Was it supposed to be harder than that? Fortunately for me, many people agree that kind of thing is bad. Counter question: Suppose something were objectively bad, in whatever means you intend that to mean, but everyone subjectively didn’t think so? Like, say, things colored cyan were objectively “Bad”. But no one knew or cared or ever would. What consequence does that have? Seems our subjective evaluations are generally what matter either way.

In an atheistic utilitarian regime you could still say Hitler’s actions were bad because they caused pain and destruction for millions of people, far beyond any possible positive aspects of his actions. Even if you only view humans as walking bags of meat, Hitler’s actions were rationally bad because resources were wasted.

Hitler got ten million Germans killed, destroyed Nazism public image, made half of Germany a Russian puppet state, fail to expand Germany and didn't get rid of all the Jews. By his own standards he would be bad. (This answer was neither a endorsement or condemnation of Hitler)

From my point of view, Hitler’s actions were bad. From Hitler’s viewpoint, they were probably pretty good. (Right up until the end, when he realized that if he didn’t pull the trigger, some Russian, French, British or American would.)

You don’t. Hitler’s actions were for the sake of a desperate nation that got a raw deal following their defeat in World War I. So if you were German, Hitler’s actions seemed like a very righteous move to keep Germany from being bankrupt until the early 80’s.
